Homer Wells.Action: As a baby, Homer lets out a happy squeal when in Larch’s arms, showing a natural warmth despite being returned by adoptive parents.
Is returned by adoptive parents because he ‘never makes a sound’ and is ‘too happy,’ indicating a lack of connection or expected response to them.
As a baby, he did not cry enough for his adopting parents, causing them to return him.
Immediately lets out a happy squeal when held by Dr. Larch, showing comfort and normal child behavior.
Listens intently with stethoscope to sounds of unborn child, showing concentration and medical interest.
Appears as a young child being returned after abuse, with no direct action shown demonstrating skill or confidence.
Reaches out and takes the pregnant woman's hand to comfort her.
Looks adoringly at Dr. Larch while learning.
Bored and looks out the window during instruction, showing lack of engagement.
Continues to return to the orphanage despite difficulties, indicating attachment and sincerity.
Reaches out and takes the hand of the crying, pregnant woman to comfort her and reassures her that everyone is nice here.
Looks bored and distracted while being instructed by Larch from 'Gray's Anatomy' and gazes out the window instead of paying attention.
Assists Dr. Larch in delivering a baby, indicating practical involvement and skill acquisition in medical procedures.
Looks with disgust at the contents of the enamel pail destined for the incinerator.
Stands uncomfortably watching Dr. Larch, then turns away quietly.
Calls out to Dr. Larch and reports about new patients in a straightforward manner.
Assists Dr. Larch effectively in delivering a baby, walking briskly with confidence and professionalism.
Stands uncomfortably while watching Dr. Larch taking ether, then briefly leaves the room instead of immediately interacting or assisting.
Calls out to Dr. Larch to inform him of two new patients including one to deliver, demonstrating awareness and communication.
Expresses reluctance to perform abortions but shows respect for Larch's choice to do so and does not argue with him.
Mumbles to himself 'Of use, of use, of use,' reflecting internal conflict and desire to be helpful.
Expresses reluctance to perform abortions, citing legal and ethical concerns; shows awareness of limits in his skills and moral boundaries.
Does not argue or challenge Dr. Larch's teaching methods or ethical stance, but instead reflects quietly on being 'of use', suggesting thoughtfulness and acceptance of his role.
Reassures Carla gently after delivery, telling her she and the baby will be okay despite her distress.
Shows concern and attention while examining Dorothy's medical condition alongside Larch.
Successfully delivers a baby and reassures the mother Carla with calm, confident words.
Discusses with Larch the unusual state of Dorothy's uterus and quickly notes it looks like scurvy, showing observation and medical reasoning.
Shows some mystification and asks relevant questions about Dorothy's condition, indicating ongoing engagement and desire to understand the problem.
Correctly identifies the substance as an aborticide and understands the medical consequences of oil of tansy leading to scurvy.
Responds annoyed but responsibly empties the basin contents when asked by Larch.
Declines Buster's offer to help carry the pail despite the task being physically demanding.
Gently corrects Buster about being a doctor, insists he is not one despite Buster's admiration
Takes care to operate a humidified tent for fragile premature baby Fuzzy
Speaks thoughtfully and respectfully about Fuzzy's medical condition
Dismissively tells Mary Agnes her bitten tongue will be all right and denies her playful come-on.
Examines Mary Agnes' tongue carefully, assesses the injury calmly and reassures her it will be all right.
Dismisses Mary Agnes' playful provocation without losing focus or reacting emotionally.
Listens quietly and accepts Dr. Larch's nightly reading and benediction with the other boys.
Silently agrees with the other boys about Dr. Larch’s love and the comforting ritual.
Does not intervene or react negatively when the boys and girls engage in a rough snowball fight.
Examines babies carefully and helps with medical checks, attentive to orphan care.
Tired of the game when asked about naming a baby, showing some frustration but no hostility.
Examines babies carefully alongside Dr. Larch, helping check their physical conditions.
Seems tired of the naming game but remains engaged in the process.
Plays along gently with Larch in naming the baby, showing patience and kindness.
Correctly identifies the baby's gender by referring to records and confidently names the child accordingly.
Takes the initiative to name the child without hesitation, demonstrating decisiveness and knowledge of the setting.
Overhears Larch's lecture attentively, showing awareness of the institutional philosophy and care for orphans.
Comforts Curly, lifts him up, carries his suitcase, and reassures him emotionally.
Engages in honest but sensitive communication with Curly about adoption prospects.
Carefully offers help to a distraught pregnant woman; despite initial hesitation, he touches and listens to the baby, showing compassion and willingness to engage.
Says he thinks about leaving but not to find his biological parents, as they didn't do the things parents are supposed to do, giving credit instead to Dr. Larch and nurses.
Compliments Buster sincerely on his cooking skills and laughs warmly at Buster's driving skills.
Reassures Buster that he knows he would never kill anyone after Buster expresses shame about a previous statement.
Describes Mary Agnes as 'just an emotional girl' after she spits at soldiers, showing a somewhat empathetic but detached understanding.
Acknowledges that Mary Agnes, like the rest of them, was left behind, demonstrating a shared sense of abandonment and implicit empathy.
Describes Mary Agnes as 'just an emotional girl' calmly in response to her anger and aggression toward the soldiers.
Shows uncertainty by shrugging and admitting he doesn't know why Mary Agnes is so emotional.
Sits mesmerized and completely focused on the King Kong film, showing engagement and attention to detail.
Gets angry and blames Larch for the broken film splice, escalating tension instead of deescalating.
Reluctantly accepts to splice the film after Larch offers to deliver, avoiding further conflict.
Adjusts Fuzzy's breathing tent carefully as the boys go to bed, showing care and attentiveness.
Argues with Larch about responsibility for the broken film splice, displaying frustration but also standing his ground.
Tries to avoid a conflict with Larch despite being upset, showing emotional self-control.
Prefers to fix the movie splice rather than assisting with a medical delivery despite being a skilled surgeon.
Adjusts Fuzzy's breathing tent attentively, showing practical caregiving competence.
Delicately examines the frightened young girl alongside Larch, assisting gently and quietly during a difficult medical procedure.
Delicately and carefully examines the young girl’s abdomen, assisting Larch in the medical procedure with care and gentleness.
Whispers the assessment that the girl is at least five months pregnant, showing his ability to make medical judgments.
Holds the frightened twelve-year-old girl still so that Larch can examine her.
Leans over the sink and splashes cold water on his face after learning the girl suffered severe injury due to lack of timely abortion care.
Becomes furious and leaves the operating room after Larch reprimands him for inaction in the girl's earlier care.
Holds the girl still so that Larch can examine her, shows willingness to assist in a difficult situation.
Closes his eyes while staring into the speculum, possibly overwhelmed or hesitant.
Pulls off his surgical mask and splashes water on his face, indicating stress or inability to cope immediately.
Is confronted by Larch about the consequences of his past refusal to perform a D and C, highlighting his inexperience or lack of assertiveness earlier.
Furious reaction to Larch’s criticism and leaves the operating room, showing emotional response but not necessarily constructive action.
Rolls his eyes when Larch explains the reasons for the child's death, showing impatience with the concept of responsibility.
Looks away uncomfortably when Larch challenges his stance regarding the child's responsibility.
Engages in conversation and listens to Larch despite obvious frustration.
Storms down the hall angrily, pulls off his white coat, kicks at nothing in frustration.
Rolled his eyes at Larch's argument about responsibility and secrecy, showing impatience but also critical thinking.
Engages in a thoughtful conversation with Larch about responsibility and control, showing willingness to think and respond.
Looks away uncomfortably when confronted about the child's responsibility, indicating some internal conflict or avoidance.
Tries to reframe Buster's bleak situation positively by emphasizing survival and companionship.
Calmly puts potential dangers in perspective to Buster, highlighting survival over circumstances.
Engages in thoughtful reflection about being alive despite difficulties.
Appears distracted or less focused when luxury car with visitors arrives.
Apologizes to Wally for the orphans not being used to seeing a car like his.
Explains to Wally that the orphans aren't used to seeing a car like his, showing awareness and communication skills.
Conducts the meeting with Candy and Wally politely and systematically, asking relevant questions like how many months Candy is, indicating professionalism.
Answers Wally honestly about not performing the abortion, defers to Dr. Larch.
Agrees promptly to attend to a newborn boy's circumcision without complaint.
Engages Wally in friendly conversation after surgery, showing interest.
Mentions heart defect bluntly and without complaint regarding military enlistment.
Confidently accepts responsibility to perform a circumcision, showing readiness and composure.
Writes down Candy's pregnancy status and communicates clearly to others, demonstrating attention to detail and clarity.
Engages in calm conversation with Wally about flying and enlistment, showing social ease and awareness but not directly related to competence in professional skills.
Shows appreciation for Wally's joke despite his own serious heart condition.
Follows Candy being wheeled out slowly, looking after her.
Calmly answers Fuzzy's questions despite being distracted, showing patience.
Warns Fuzzy not to get too excited about pumpkins due to health concerns.
Asks Wally if anyone has offered him food, showing concern for another’s well-being.
Seeks a ride with Wally despite not knowing the destination, indicating trust and willingness to connect.
Looks out the window at Wally with a decision forming, hinting at internal conflict or contemplation (non-action/omission).
Looks thoughtful and distracted when asked about Halloween, giving an imprecise answer.
Sees a situation (Fuzzy’s deteriorating health) and seems to make a decision, showing some awareness and concern.
Approaches Wally to ask about food and requests a ride despite not knowing the destination, showing social initiative but lack of preparation.
Accepts to go to Cape Kenneth without knowing where it is, showing lack of knowledge and poor planning.
Runs eagerly up stairs, full of energy and excitement, but stops abruptly when unexpectedly confronted by Dr. Larch, indicating some impulsiveness but also responsiveness.
Expresses gratitude to Larch despite feeling trapped and criticized.
Restrained but polite in conversation with Larch, avoiding confrontation.
Accepts the heart X ray calmly without argument, showing trust and sincerity.
States he expects to find ways to be of use when leaving, showing intention and some confidence.
Appears restrained and somewhat trapped during confrontation with Larch, unable to assert himself fully.
Expresses gratitude and acknowledges Larch's help, reflecting emotional intelligence but possibly lacks assertiveness.
Dismisses the heart X-ray as unnecessary because he knows about his condition, but then accepts it when Larch insists, showing some internal conflict and hesitance.
Gratefully receives clothes from Larch, feels ashamed but does not refuse kindness.
Refuses to take money directly from Edna, but allows it to be placed in his suitcase.
Quietly packs his belongings and accepts clothes and money from others, showing preparedness for leaving.
Refuses to verbally respond to offers of help but accepts help non-verbally, indicating thoughtful restraint rather than confusion.
Says goodbye to the children, embracing them.
Tells Curly he has to go, expresses regret but cannot finish his words.
Can't look at Curly who looks betrayed.
Does not find Buster to say goodbye, asks Edna to tell him.
Gets in the car quietly and observes surroundings during the drive.
Says goodbye to the children with affection, showing emotional intelligence and responsibility.
Gets in the car to accompany Wally and Candy on the trip as a doctor, indicating readiness and professional responsibility.
Avoids facing Curly who looks betrayed, and struggles to communicate fully, showing emotional difficulty but also awareness.
Responds to Candy's groggy comment with interest in the apple business, tries to engage her despite the boring nature of the work.
Expresses a sincere willingness to work in an unfamiliar, labor-intensive apple picking job despite being seen as overqualified.
Tries to engage Candy in conversation showing social initiative in a difficult context.
Passively listens to Wally and Candy's back-and-forth but maintains his position on needing a job.
Tries to engage Candy in conversation with gentle questions about her family and experiences.
Responds briefly and quietly to Candy's emotional distress with minimal verbal comfort ('I know.', 'I understand.'), revealing limited emotional connection.
Remains present and silent while Candy sobs alone in the car, showing tolerance but no active comforting.
Tries to engage Candy in conversation to ease tension.
Pretends not to hear Wally's excessive peeing, showing social awareness and discretion.
Responds empathetically to Candy's emotional distress with simple affirmations like 'I know' and 'I understand', despite not fully grasping her situation.
Shows nervousness while smoking outside after overhearing Candy's weeping, indicating internal struggle but also self-control.
Reassures Candy about the abortion procedure and its effects, speaking in a calm, medical manner to reduce her worry.
Smokes a cigarette nervously but stops smoking when Wally admonishes him, showing respect and consideration.
Engages attentively with Candy's concerns about her bleeding and cramps, providing detailed and comforting information.
Explains medical effects of abortion procedure calmly and accurately to Candy and Wally.
Smokes nervously despite the stressful situation but stops when confronted by Wally's authority.
Responds confidently and knowledgeably to Candy's concerns about bleeding and cramping.
Throws a football; it's clear he's never thrown one before.
Listens thoughtfully to Wally's explanation about the Burma run and asks relevant questions about altitude and flight.
Expresses enthusiasm about picking apples with Wally despite not sharing his enthusiasm for flying.
Politely responds to Candy's thanks and says he'll see her around; shakes her hand.

Observes his surroundings quietly and appreciatively (admiring the farmhouse) without taking initiative.
Responds politely and shyly to Mrs. Worthington's greeting despite unfamiliarity.
Appears confused about the wedding and is embarrassed when Wally calls him everyone's friend.
Appears eager to learn the apple business despite being described as overqualified, showing willingness and humility.
Looks confused and seems to have forgotten about the alleged wedding, indicating a lack of social awareness or situational attentiveness.
Is embarrassed by Wally's boast that he is 'everybody's friend,' suggesting some social awkwardness or discomfort.
Responds genuinely with 'Migrants?' showing honest curiosity and openness to learning about others.
Introduced politely to the Rose family and shakes hands with Mr. Rose; interacts respectfully with others around.
Shows no dismissiveness or prejudice toward the migrant workers around him, indicating tolerance.
Fails to understand what migrants are when first introduced to the concept.
Introduces himself politely to Mr. Rose and makes a positive first impression by shaking hands confidently.
Appears unsure and passive when told to let Mr. Rose be the boss, showing lack of insight into local social dynamics.

Works diligently to clean and organize the messy shed without complaint.

Thinks over Mr. Rose's advice about doing one job before another and proceeds to clean out the shed.

Openly shows and explains his heart X-ray and health condition without defensiveness.
Explains clearly and accurately the condition of his heart using the X-ray image for Rose Rose's understanding.

Notices Rose Rose's interest in reading and politely engages her by reading aloud to her and the others.
Smiles politely at Rose Rose's embarrassment about not being able to read and continues reading to include her.
Reads passages thoughtfully, showing sensitivity to the content and the mood of the listeners.
Reads aloud confidently and accurately from 'Great Expectations' to an audience unfamiliar with reading, demonstrating literacy and patience.
Politely engages with Rose Rose about reading but does not press or show frustration when met with embarrassment or lack of knowledge, showing social sensitivity though a passive approach.
Interprets and reads the list of rules to the group on demand, showing ability to handle social leadership roles and interpret written information for others.
Reads aloud the rules despite others' reluctance, showing willingness to share and engage.

Lies awake quietly after lights out, not disturbing others.

Spills some apples lifting the crate to the loading platform.
Smiles and runs toward Wally when called, showing social ease and responsiveness.
Expresses gratitude for the simple work of picking apples and seems content with the job, showing a grounded and practical attitude but no particular skill or confidence demonstrated.
Accepts the responsibility to help Wally and his family during Wally's absence, showing a willingness to take on a trusted role despite awkwardness.
Laughs and shakes hands with Wally after an unfamiliar kind of teasing, showing openness and friendliness.
Listens attentively and earnestly to Mr. Rose’s instructions on apple picking, showing respect and willingness to learn.
Nods and picks more carefully after receiving guidance, showing sincerity and a cooperative attitude.

Listens carefully to Mr. Rose's instructions, adjusts technique with more concentration, and improves his picking skill.
Described as an accomplished gynecological obstetrical surgeon experienced in pediatric care.
Lacks formal diplomas but is supported by Larch, who fabricates credentials to protect him.

Does not have formal diplomas or official credentials, requiring Dr. Larch to fabricate documents to assert his qualifications.
Climbs up to join the group on the roof, sits with them despite feeling unsure about the rules, and smiles at their teasing.

Helps the pickers load crates of apples cooperatively.

Asks Candy if she has been feeling okay, showing concern for her well-being.

Responds awkwardly in conversation, indicating some social discomfort.
Sends a gift of carefully picked apples despite likely financial sacrifice.
Picks and sends apples as a gift, showing thoughtfulness and engagement in practical tasks.
Does not write a detailed letter or explanation with the gift, causing frustration and misunderstanding.
Engages in playful teasing and banter with Candy, smiles and enjoys the interaction, showing comfort and friendliness.

Declares Candy is the nicest and most beautiful girl he has ever known.
Keeps picking apples quietly despite others suggesting he is in trouble.

Continues picking apples calmly even when others suggest he is in trouble, showing composed behavior.
Has a resume described as 'pathetic' by Larch but considered the best by him, indicating some recognized competence despite others' low expectations.
Leans in to talk to Candy despite the rain, getting soaking wet.

Questions about worms in apples, showing curiosity and awareness about quality and health factors in cider making.
Offers to properly treat Mr. Rose's wound when Rose Rose is struggling.

Insists he knows how to properly stitch a wound, showing medical skill and professionalism compared to Rose Rose's amateur efforts.

Shares a personal, vulnerable memory about loneliness in the orphanage, showing openness and sincerity.
Tries to lighten the mood after sharing something deep by making a light, somewhat awkward joke.

Makes light of feeling exposed to ease the mood.

Does not call to inquire about Fuzzy's condition or death; shows distance.
Shakes the package, sets it aside unopened, and only later quietly opens it a little before putting it away unopened again.

Retrieves candy's piece of glass when she throws it toward the water, engages playfully and physically affectionate by chasing and holding her gently.
Responds to Candy's emotional conversation with quiet presence and agreement, providing non-verbal support.
Retrieves the piece of glass Candy throws into the water and engages playfully with her, showing attentiveness and physical coordination.
Concentrates on starting the car despite emotional tension, showing focus under pressure.

Waves goodbye to pickers and responds to their calls with calmness and good humor.

Carefully learning lobster fishing with Ray and Candy, showing humility and patience.
Gets pinched by lobster while trying to disarm the claws, demonstrating willingness to learn and participate despite discomfort.
Expresses tender and sincere feelings toward Candy, showing emotional vulnerability and genuine affection.
Writes a letter that Edna, Angela, and Larch read with silent appreciation, indicating trustworthiness and openness.
Enjoys simple life as lobsterman and orchardman, wanting to be of use to those around him, showing sincere desire to help and belong.
Following Ray's example, trying to 'disarm' lobster claws but gets pinched while Roy works quickly without getting pinched.
Expresses that he is not a doctor and enjoys his life as a lobsterman and orchardman, showing self-awareness and contentment.
Engages emotionally with Candy, showing vulnerability but not directly related to competence.

Sheepishly thanks Olive when she offers him blankets.
Works cooperatively with Vernon in the orchards to poison mice.
Reflects sincerely on what he’s learning and shows humility about the limits of his knowledge.

Is distracted while driving, having difficulty keeping his eyes on the road because of emotional preoccupation.

Removes the list of rules from the wall and paints over the spot, then retacks the rules on a support beam, showing care in how he treats the environment and the rules.
Expresses doubt and inability to replace Dr. Larch, showing humility and emotional sincerity.

Carefully removes the list of rules from the wall to paint beneath it and then reattaches it to a support beam, showing conscientiousness and orderliness.
Expresses doubt in his ability to replace Larch as doctor, saying 'I can't replace you,' indicating lack of confidence.

Responds to the abrupt change in music by dancing goofily, breaking the mood.
Interacts playfully and confidently with Candy, engaging in pillow fight and showing ease in social interaction.
Tries to help Candy by adding details about Wally's bombing, but stops when he realizes she is tired of hearing it.

Accuses Mr. Rose repeatedly in a blunt and confrontational manner.

Puts his face in his hands upon hearing Candy's distress, then apologizes sincerely.
Replies to Candy's anguished cries about Wally's injury with calm, factual statements and expresses his love for her.
Demonstrates emotionally detached, almost mocking behavior earlier in the exchange by making light of Candy's anger and decisions.
Turns away from Candy when she asks what to do, stating calmly that she doesn't have to do anything, showing emotional distancing.
Avoids making decisions by passively waiting, expresses irritation but does not take immediate effective action in a crisis.
After regaining composure, shows calm resolve and a measured response to Candy's distress, indicating emotional self-control and understanding the limits of his role.
Steps between Mr. Rose and Rose Rose to protect her from a struggle.
Offers Rose Rose help and reassures her she doesn't have to go anywhere.
Focuses on his medical instruments and ignores Mr. Rose's antagonistic questions.
Steps between Rose Rose and Mr. Rose to intervene in their struggle, asserts himself despite opposition.
Calmly and confidently explains his medical profession and offers help to Rose Rose.
Prepares medical instruments methodically for an upcoming procedure, scrubs hands, wears surgical mask.
Confidently declares, 'No *almost* about it--I'm a doctor.'
Calmly organizes surgical equipment by naming them one by one.
Takes charge by clearing the room and focusing on the procedure.
Performs a difficult abortion under pressure with attentive focus.
Notices Mr. Rose struggling to breathe and advises him to get some air.
Puts away his instruments quietly and respectfully during a sensitive moment.
Reads the house rules aloud when asked, showing cooperation and attentiveness to others' wishes.
Puts away his instruments efficiently after use.
Reads the rules aloud clearly when requested, demonstrating responsibility and willingness to lead.
Crinkles the list of rules and throws it into the stove, signaling rejection of unfair rules imposed on his community.
Agrees with the community's ownership of their own rules, showing solidarity and respect for others' autonomy.
Responds simply and without elaboration when confronted about the meaning of the rules, suggesting possible reserved or withdrawn demeanor.
Tries to understand Candy's feelings and motivations by asking questions and reflecting on how he helped her emotionally.
Responds to Candy's emotional outburst with sarcasm and emotional detachment, showing an almost clinical curiosity rather than empathy.
Able to remain impervious to emotional manipulation or distress from Candy, demonstrating emotional resilience.
Turns away from Candy and the emotional situation to stare at a blank screen, showing avoidance rather than engaging or resolving conflict.
Attempts to examine Mr. Rose's wound and shows concern for both Mr. Rose and Muddy.
Does not respond verbally to Mr. Rose's fatal prognosis, but his silence implies understanding and empathy.
Takes initiative by quickly running toward the cider house upon hearing the news about Rose Rose.
Attempts to examine Mr. Rose's wound, showing calmness and willingness to help despite the grave situation.
Remains silent and composed when Mr. Rose reveals the situation, indicating awareness of the hopelessness but doesn’t panic or lose control.
Does not provide explicit advice or leadership when Muddy looks to him for guidance, showing a possible hesitation or lack of assertive response to pressure.
Closes Mr. Rose's eyes after he dies.
Follows Mr. Rose's instructions to lie to the police about the situation.
Accurately assesses the severity of Mr. Rose's injuries, noting multiple lacerations.
Maintains composure under physical threat when Mr. Rose grabs him by the throat.
Subtly complies with Mr. Rose's demand to lie to the police without openly resisting or escalating the situation.
Assures Candy that Wally will be fine and acknowledges her warning, touching her tear away gently.
Puts the unopened letter from St. Cloud's in his pocket without comment or discussion.
Reads letter about Wilbur with no enthusiasm, quietly processes Dr. Larch's death.
Opens and reads Angela's letter about Wilbur calmly and without visible enthusiasm.
Finishes reading the letter, puts it down, and silently walks to the window, implying thoughtful processing and self-control.
Wipes a tear off his cheek after reading the letter, showing emotional sensitivity but maintaining composure.
Sits quietly and looks thoughtfully at the apple farm while others try to engage him in conversation, indicating resolve and thoughtful decision-making.
Smiles and shakes his head when asked about seeing a palm tree, showing awareness of his own experience limitations with gentle humor.
Does not engage much in conversation with pickers, possibly indicating social hesitance or withdrawal rather than lack of competence.
Smiles and shakes his head at friends joking about moving somewhere warm, showing gentle tolerance but choosing his own path.
Quietly watches the house disappear from view, suggesting a reflective and sincere demeanor.
Decides to leave the familiar environment (Maine) and move on alone despite peer encouragement to stay, indicating self-awareness and confident decision-making.
Appears somber and reflective as he faces an uncertain future, showing thoughtful introspection and measured emotional control.
Silently resists the group's persuasion to stay, suggesting quiet resolve and independence.
Carries Dr. Larch's bag and suitcase, walks up the hill confidently toward the orphanage despite disapproval around him.
Arrives at orphanage and embraces children and staff warmly, showing emotional intelligence and acceptance of responsibility.
Gives Curly a piece of pale-green glass from the ocean as a gift.
Smiles and accepts offered help from Mary Agnes and Angela with unpacking and room arrangements.
Reacts with stunned silence upon learning about the heart surgery deception, shows vulnerability and openness.
Reads to the boys from 'David Copperfield' with a strong, positive, and reassuring voice, and smiles when asked about the next part of the story, choosing to keep the boys engaged and hopeful.
Delivers Larch's popular blessing warmly to the boys, addressing them affectionately as 'Princes of Maine' and 'Kings of New England.'
Hesitates and skips a line or two in the reading, possibly to avoid something discouraging, showing sensitivity to the boys' feelings.
Reads to the boys with a strong, positive, and reassuring voice, engaging them with a smile and knows how to build suspense by not revealing the whole story.
Hesitates and skips some lines while reading, distracted and possibly uncertain about what comes next.
